awd_titl_txt: Digital technology integration and engineering contexts to support elementary students' systems thinking
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Research has indicated limited digital technology use and engineering instruction among elementary teachers. This project addresses two of the seven ITEST guiding questions: student experiences with emerging technologies and instructional and curricular innovations. The Making Engineering Real (ME-REAL) project will develop and implement professional development (PD) to support teachers who work with high populations of underrepresented students in STEM to develop richer, more authentic STEM education through: (a) technology-rich instruction, (b) authentic engineering opportunities, and (c) the development of systems thinking skills. The project will provide guidelines for technology integration within elementary engineering contexts that can inform expectations beyond Virginia. These guidelines will also inform interventions involving secondary teachers to support the development and integration of more comprehensive and increasingly complex technology use within STEM instruction. The project impacts the competencies essential for students to be successful in STEM-related degree programs and careers and is focused on better preparing elementary and secondary science teachers, providing them with valuable instructional tools. Because of this project, students will have more opportunities to engineer within authentic contexts, use relevant technologies in ways that reflect the work of scientists, and think about systems critically. 

Prior research indicates teacher beliefs must be elicited and addressed to support changes in instructional practices. However, the question remains as to the extent interventions that incorporate attention to beliefs leads to instructional change. Comparison of ME-REAL teachers' innovation adoption rates to adoption rates cited in other studies in which the intervention included modeling, practice, planning, and coaching, but not attention to beliefs will allow the determination of the extent attending to beliefs promotes instructional change and innovation adoption, especially in the domain of computer simulations. The goal of ME-REAL is to increase and improve 1) elementary teachers' instruction and students' engagement and understanding in the STEM domains of engineering, digital technology, and systems thinking and 2) elementary student science learning among traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM (e.g. rural, Black, Hispanic, low socioeconomic status). Through a delayed-treatment quasi-experimental design, the ME-REAL project will advance the understanding of (1) pedagogies (e.g. digital technology integration) and engineering contexts that effectively support elementary students' systems thinking, (2) PD that facilitates teachers' systems thinking, engineering understandings, and digital technology use, and (3) the extent to which attending to teachers' beliefs during PD promotes instructional change and innovation adoption. Results from this ME-REAL project have implications for designing curricular tools and scaffolds to develop students' critical thinking about systems in all STEM domains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project titled “Digital technology integration and engineering contexts to support elementary students' systems thinking” (ME REAL) provided sustained professional development (PD) to elementary teachers in central and southwestern Virginia. The project served a total of 32 teachers for one or more years with 20 teachers participating in PD for multiple years. The PD focused on engineering, technology, and systems thinking integration. Teachers modified their instruction to include grade-relevant digital technology, engineering, and systems thinking. Thus, ME REAL impacted approximately 1,000 elementary students in Virginia across the life of the project. The project resulted in 12 presentations at research conferences, 2 presentations at practitioner conferences, 2 published conference proceedings, 6 submitted manuscripts, and 2 manuscripts in progress.

Over the course of the grant, the project also supported research and professional growth of three post-doctoral research associates and 4 undergraduate students. Each of the three post-docs presented project-related research at one or more national conferences, developed and submitted manuscripts for peer-reviewed journals, mentored undergraduate research assistants, and obtained employment at an institute of higher education following their post-doctoral experience.

Results of this project have implications for future work. One goal of the project was to identify a reasonable digital technology integration progression to support technology-enhanced engineering integration for the elementary grades. Results from years 1 through 3 of the project indicated images, animations, computer simulations, block-based coding, and spreadsheets were accessible instructional technologies for most teachers and their students. Teachers of grade K-2 students primarily integrated technologies in whole group settings while teachers of students in grades 3-5 integrated in whole class, small group, and one-to-one settings. These findings have implications for developing teachers’ technological pedagogical knowledge. Specifically, while spreadsheets, simulations, block-based coding, and interactive visualizations are all appropriate in all the elementary grades, integration should be done whole group in the younger grades to model productive and appropriate use of the technology so that students can work independently in later elementary grades. Elementary teachers need to be comfortable modeling use of these technologies for STEM learning and guiding students to develop modeled skills.

In addition, results indicated prior to instruction, elementary teachers typically perceived cycles as systems, were most familiar with man-made engineered systems, and were not confident teaching systems thinking to students. In year 4 of the project, ME REAL built upon participants’ initial knowledge to develop and implement a sequence of PD to build teachers’ understandings of systems to include inputs, outputs, and boundaries. Results have already been shared at two national conferences (Gonczi et al., 2024; Maeng et al., 2024) and will be presented at a workshop in January 2025 at the annual ASTE conference. A manuscript describing this PD is in progress and upon publication will be of value to in-service and pre-service teachers, providing effective learning activities and sequences to increase their understanding of and instruction about systems and systems thinking.

In the last year of the project, participants had the opportunity to share what they learned in the PD and develop professional writing skills. Three participants developed manuscripts for Science and Children, published through the National Science Teachers’ Association, that described new instructional strategies and/or lessons they developed and implemented during participation. At this time, two of these manuscripts are in revision and one is under review. Upon publication, these manuscripts will amplify the number of teachers that are potentially impacted by the project as well as build leadership capacity among the teacher authors.

Overall, ME REAL positively impacted Virginia elementary teachers and students, developed academic professionals in STEM education, and findings were broadly disseminated to practitioner and research audiences through conferences and publications.
